The structure of hydrate is also important for the development of hydrate-based carbon dioxide storage technology. In this work, we report the structure of hydrate formed by neon, a gas that is not normally considered to be a hydrate-forming gas. The structure of neon hydrate is different from that of other hydrate-forming gases, such as methane and carbon dioxide. This work provides a new perspective on the structure of hydrate and its formation mechanism. It also provides a new method for the formation of hydrate with a different gas. Quantum mechanics is a mathematical theory that has been very successful in describing the behavior of microscopic particles. However, it is not a theory that is easy to understand. This is partly because it is based on a mathematical formalism that is unfamiliar to many people. In this paper, we provide a mathematical foundation for quantum mechanics that is based on a familiar mathematical structure: Hilbert spaces. We show that the axioms of quantum mechanics can be expressed purely in terms of the structure of a category of Hilbert spaces. This provides a mathematical foundation for quantum mechanics that is both familiar and rigorous.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in a wide range of hosts. Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we present the first genome assemblies for two species of myxozoans, which represent the sister group to the Myxozoa, and compare these to the genome of a less reduced cnidarian parasite. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides insights into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Less)

The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic has caused a global health crisis. The SARS-CoV-2 virus is able to evade the host immune response by blocking the nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are essential for the induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). In this study, we show that the viral accessory protein Orf6 is responsible for this anti-IFN activity. We found that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and interacts with Nup98-Rae1, a protein complex that mediates nuclear import. We also show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its anti-IFN activity. Our findings provide a mechanism of viral antagonism that could be used by other pathogens to evade the antiviral action of IFN. This knowledge could be used to design new antiviral strategies against COVID-19. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. Mutations of some Hv1 residues affect only Zn2+ inhibition of the voltage sensor motion, whereas mutations of other residues also affect Zn2+ inhibition of gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. Climate change will affect global food production, but the magnitude of the changes is difficult to predict because of the complexity of the system. Here, we use a global dataset of maize production and climate variability to quantify how maize yields will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase almost everywhere, and the probability that they have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase. These results highlight the need for investments in breeding for heat tolerance. They also underscore the urgency of these investments, as the world will need to increase maize production by 50% by 2050 to meet the needs of a growing population.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is important for understanding the mechanisms of coexistence in large herbivore communities. However, the extent to which species differ in their diets has been difficult to quantify because of the difficulty of species-level identification of plant material in feces. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammal species in semiarid African savanna. We found that species differed in their diets, even when they were matched in body size and digestive physiology. These differences were reflected in high dietary overlap between species that were similar in diet composition, but not in diet breadth. Our results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large herbivore communities. Our findings also highlight the importance of plant diversity in structuring large herbivore communities. This is important because the loss of plant diversity is one of the most significant drivers of biodiversity loss worldwide.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses, which are the backbone of the US economy. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of COVID-19 on their operations. We find that many small businesses are financially fragile, and that many more are at risk of closing. However, many small businesses are also taking advantage of the CARES Act, and we find evidence that the CARES Act is helping some businesses survive the crisis.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to the size-selective sinks of plastic debris on the open ocean surface, which involve a combination of processes that are still to be identified. This work provides a better understanding of the fate of plastic debris in the ocean and is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in astronomy. The solar system is a unique laboratory for studying the origin of the universe. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga before the start of the Solar System ∼4.6 Ga ago. A majority of the grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. This suggests that the solar system formed in a short period of time after the formation of the first stars.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded substantially. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is one of the most important traits in nature. In this study, we investigate the factors that limit reproductive output in mammals and find that it is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. We find that the greatest increase in reproductive output is in species that practice allonursing, where the mother cares for the offspring after birth. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This finding has implications for understanding the evolution of mammalian reproductive strategies and the evolution of domestication and allomaternal care. It also has implications for understanding the evolution of human reproductive strategies. Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes. The inflammatory protease caspase-1 has recently been implicated in the mechanisms that promote aggregation of α-syn in vitro and in neuronal cell models of α-syn toxicity. In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the progressive toxicity of α-syn aggregation in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn and with neuroprotective effects in the substantia nigra of the mouse model. These results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This study provides an in vivo proof of concept for the use of VX-765 in MSA and other synucleinopathies. This study also provides a rationale for the use of caspase-1 inhibitors in the treatment of other neurodegenerative diseases. This is the first study to show that a caspase-1 inhibitor is able to limit the toxicity of α-syn aggregation in vivo. This

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most numerous cell type in the body. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are specialized to detect and respond to multiple stimuli. The endothelium is also responsible for controlling the contractility of blood vessels, hemostasis, and inflammation. The endothelium is a complex system that is composed of thousands of specialized cells that are connected to each other in a network. The network is responsible for integrating multiple lines of information and coordinating the endothelium’s responses. Here, the nature of the communication network has been addressed using single-cell Ca2+ imaging across thousands of endothelial cells in intact blood vessels. The findings reveal that the endothelium is a highly connected, small-world network that is effective for local and global communication. The network is also highly dynamic and robust. These findings provide a detailed description of the communication network that is responsible for controlling the cardiovascular system. The findings have implications for understanding the endothelium’s role in health and disease.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, especially for public health surveillance and epidemiological modeling. We describe the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 signals, including many auxiliary indicators that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These signals are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The COVIDcast API also tracks all revisions to historical data, allowing modelers to account for the frequent revisions and backfill that are common for many public health data sources. The COVIDcast API is a resource that we hope will be useful to epidemiologists, researchers, and policy makers in their efforts to understand and respond to the pandemic.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes, such as the control of heart rate and blood pressure, the transmission of nerve impulses, and the regulation of muscle contraction. The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel and is responsible for the selective permeation of K+ ions. The selectivity filter is also the site of the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the inactivation gate. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the activation gate as the key residue for this allosteric communication. We have shown that this residue is crucial for the structural stability of the selectivity filter.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to be important for the health of the host. However, the mechanisms by which the microbiome regulates the host are poorly understood. Here, we investigate the potential of anaerobic gut fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate membership within the gut microbiome. We found that anaerobic gut fungi synthesize a variety of natural products, including antibiotics, antimicrobials, and antimicrobials that are unique to anaerobic fungi. These results support the hypothesis that anaerobic fungi are important contributors to the natural product diversity of the gut microbiome. This work provides a foundation for the discovery of novel natural products from anaerobic fungi and the development of these fungi as a source of bioactive compounds. Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the mechanisms underlying the establishment of social hierarchy remain largely unknown. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with a low probability to become dominant, directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats. We further identify an important role for brain energy metabolism in the nucleus accumbens, a brain region that is involved in the establishment of social hierarchy. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of anxiety in social behavior and may lead to the development of new therapeutic approaches for anxiety-related social disorders. The ability to precisely control the mechanical response of a device is critical for its functionality. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we use a digital synthesis approach to synthesize multiple hyperelastic materials into composite structures that seamlessly collaborate to produce the target response. The structures are digitally synthesized to exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work provides a general framework for the design of programmable mechanical devices with complex and highly complex behaviors.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein in red blood cells. The hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythroblasts is a major determinant of the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood. In this study, we investigated the role of IGF2BP1, a protein that is involved in the heterochronic let-7 miRNA pathway, in the control of hemoglobin expression in human erythroblasts. We found that IGF2BP1 is down-regulated in human erythroblasts and that its overexpression in erythroid cells results in a nearly complete reversal of the adult hemoglobin expression pattern toward a more fetal-like pattern. This suggests that IGF2BP1 may be involved in the control of human hemoglobin expression. This study provides a potential mechanism for chronoregulation of hemoglobin expression in humans. It also provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of hemoglobinopathies. This study may also have implications for the control of hemoglobin expression in other species. Cancer cells are highly resistant to ferroptotic cell death, a form of regulated necrosis that is regulated by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This resistance is mediated by mutations in phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) or loss of phosphatase and tensin homolog deleted on chromosome 10 (PTEN), two highly frequent events in human cancer. Here, we show that these mutations protect cancer cells from ferroptosis by activating the mTOR signaling axis, which in turn induces sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. We also show that SREBP1 mediates the ferroptosis-suppressing activity of SREBP1 by producing monounsaturated fatty acids. Finally, we demonstrate that the combination of mTOR inhibition with ferroptosis induction is effective in preclinical models of cancer with PI3K or PTEN mutations. These findings suggest that mTOR inhibition may be combined with ferroptosis induction to treat cancer patients with PI3K or PTEN mutations. (PsycINFO Database Record

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The most common treatment for hypertension is the use of drugs that block the voltage-gated L-type Ca2+ channel (Cav1.2). However, these drugs are associated with a higher risk of heart failure. Here, we show that these drugs promote vascular remodeling through a mechanism involving the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stromal-interacting molecule (STIM) Ca2+ sensor. Our findings indicate that the use of these drugs should be carefully considered in patients with advanced hypertension or cardiovascular remodeling. This study provides a mechanism for the adverse effects of these drugs and may lead to the development of new drugs for the treatment of hypertension. This article is protected by copyright. The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the management of 10 million hectares of federal forest land in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP’s effects on bird populations are not as clear-cut. The NWFP halted clearcutting on federal land, but this has so far been insufficient to reverse declines in older-forest–associated bird populations. We also show that the early-seral ecosystem area was stable, but declined in two ecoregions—the Coast Range and Cascades—along with early-seral bird populations. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. Our results also highlight the importance of monitoring and adaptive management in policy evaluation.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibacterial agents is essential to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. In this work, we present a rational design approach to identify new acylide antibiotics that are active against antibiotic-resistant pathogens. The design strategy is based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. We show that the best compounds designed by us are active against antibiotic-resistant pathogens, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin. The compounds are more soluble, exhibit higher binding affinity to the ribosome, and are up to 56 times more active than telithromycin. The design strategy can be extended to other antibiotic classes. This work is expected to contribute to the development of new antibiotics to combat antibiotic resistance. Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often very large, which makes it difficult to train the networks with a large number of training samples. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is also easier to implement on embedded devices, which makes it suitable for real-time applications.

The Lake Malawi cichlid fish species flock is one of the most diverse and best-known groups of endemic species on Earth. The lake is one of the largest freshwater ecosystems in the tropics and is a critical site for understanding the evolution of biodiversity in response to environmental change. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of hydroclimate variability in the tropics, which shows that the lake has been much lower in the past, including 15 times when the lake was more than 400 m lower than today. This record provides a unique perspective on the evolution of the species flock and the role of hydroclimate variability in shaping the ecology and evolution of this remarkable group.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is increasing rapidly. This study shows that this practice has a negative impact on sleep. Specifically, reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) for 1 h before bedtime phase-decelerates the circadian clock, suppresses melatonin, and reduces the amount of sleep. These effects are likely to have important implications for performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known climate event that has been attributed to a bolide impact. However, the origin of the magnetic grains and microspherules that are abundant in the sediments at the YDB is not clear. We show that the magnetic grains and microspherules are terrestrial in origin. In addition, we show that the rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopic compositions of a rare 1.5-mm diameter spherule from the YDB site in Pennsylvania are consistent with the source being the 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. These results support the hypothesis that a bolide impact triggered the YDB.

The role of CTLA-4 in the control of autoimmunity is well established, but the consequences of its ablation in the adult mouse are not. Here, we show that ablation of CTLA-4 in adult mice leads to a spectrum of autoimmunity, which is not fatal but can be lethal in the case of congenital deficiency. This is accompanied by a shift in the balance between Th17 and Treg cells, and the disease is not completely suppressed by Treg cells alone. These findings have implications for the treatment of autoimmune diseases, as well as for the development of vaccines. They also highlight the importance of the adult immune system in the control of autoimmunity.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 154 beetle genomes and transcriptomes to trace the evolution of beetle genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose, the major component of plant cell walls. Our analyses resolved previously controversial beetle relationships, dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous, and supported the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms. Moreover, corresponding (Jurassic) diversification rate increases suggest that these novel genes triggered adaptive radiations that resulted in nearly half of all living beetle species. We propose that beetle diversity resulted from multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivores following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding cell-wall degrading enzymes.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation antibody-based therapeutics against SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work also provides a proof-of-concept for the application of deep learning in the design of other protein molecules.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We found that larger populations did not enhance CCE, but that the size of the population did affect the variation in plane performance and the quality of the planes that participants could access. These results suggest that the size of the population may be an important factor in the evolution of CCE.

The APOE gene is the strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) risk. APOE isoform is also associated with differential risk of AD. APOE is also known to be highly expressed in astrocytes, a major cell type in the brain that is involved in synapse pruning and turnover. Here, we show that APOE isoform is also associated with differential phagocytic capacity of astrocytes. APOE2 enhances the rate of phagocytosis of synapses by astrocytes, whereas APO4 decreases it. We also found that APOE4 increases the rate of C1q accumulation in the brain, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. These studies provide a mechanistic explanation for the differential risk of AD associated with APOE alleles.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is the densest part of the planet. It is believed to have formed by crystallization of a molten iron core. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. We found that the nucleation of the inner core is more likely to be a two-step process, in which the bcc phase of iron is the first nucleus. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which solves the inner core nucleation paradox. Our results provide a new perspective on the formation of the inner core and the crystallization process of iron. They also suggest that the nucleation of the inner core may be a common process in the crystallization of iron-rich materials. This study may help us understand the formation of other planetary cores and the crystallization process of iron-rich materials in the solar system and beyond.

Marijuana is the most widely used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA). This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, as well as increased negative emotionality and addiction severity. These findings highlight the need to investigate the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain. They also suggest that the brain reactivity to methylphenidate might be a useful biomarker for assessing the effects of chronic marijuana use.

Language is the most complex behavior we know of. How the human brain processes language is therefore a central question in cognitive neuroscience. We here show that the most powerful artificial neural networks for language processing also predict nearly 100% of the explainable variance in the brain’s neural responses to sentences. This suggests that the mechanisms that drive language comprehension are similar in humans and artificial neural networks. We also find that the networks’ neural fits are predictive of how well they perform on a language task. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also suggest that artificial neural networks may be a powerful tool for understanding the brain’s language mechanisms. This may lead to computational models of language processing that are more similar to the brain than any previously proposed.

Deep learning (DL) has been a revolutionary technology in many fields of science and engineering. However, it has been criticized for its instability, which is a major obstacle to its widespread use in scientific computing. We show that this instability is closely related to the numerical stability of the underlying algorithms. We prove that there are cases where it is impossible to compute a stable neural network (NN) with a given accuracy, even with infinite time and memory. This implies that the number of layers in the NN must be increased to achieve the desired accuracy. Our results provide a classification theory of the conditions under which a given accuracy can be achieved by an algorithm. They also provide a theoretical foundation for the development of more stable DL algorithms.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including a failure to understand exponential growth. This is based on a classic experiment published 45 years ago, which is often cited as evidence for this phenomenon. However, the experiment’s design flaws were not noticed at the time, and the study has become a canonical example of the phenomenon. Here, we discuss the flaws in the experiment’s design and how they led to the erroneous conclusion that people are unable to understand exponential growth. We also discuss the implications of this case study for the study of human cognition and the role of research in the public sphere.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for millennia, and its causative agent, Mycobacterium leprae, has been the subject of intense research for decades. In contrast, the pathogen that causes the rare and little-understood reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon has been known for only a few years. Here we present the genome sequence of M. lepromatosis, a pathogen that causes the more common form of leprosy, diffuse lepromatous leprosy. We also show that M. lepromatosis is more closely related to the MRCA of all leprosy bacilli than is M. leprae, and that the two pathogens have diverged only recently. This study provides a unique opportunity to compare the genomes of two leprosy pathogens and to understand the evolution of this disease. (Less)

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also the two concepts that are most difficult to study in quantum mechanics. The entanglement dynamics is the only way to understand how thermodynamics emerges in isolated quantum systems. However, it was previously known only for noninteracting systems, whereas it is believed to be impossible to compute it for interacting systems. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics can be computed for interacting systems as well, and we provide a complete description of the dynamics for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global health emergency that requires a rapid response to control the spread of the virus. The only live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine currently in clinical development, COVI-VAC, is based on a temperature-sensitive recoded virus that is more easily controlled in the laboratory and in animals. The vaccine is expected to be safe and effective in humans, and its large-scale manufacturing potential supports its potential use in mass vaccination programs. This study provides a proof of concept for a temperature-sensitive recoded vaccine that is safe, effective, and scalable for mass vaccination. This study also provides a framework for the development of other temperature-sensitive recoded vaccines for other pathogens. This work is expected to contribute to the global fight against COVID-19. The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that it was spread by rats. However, there is no evidence that plague was transmitted by rats during the Black Death (1347–1353), the most devastating plague epidemic in history. Here, we show that a model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites fits the mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death. This has important implications for our understanding of the epidemiology of the disease and its impact on human populations. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of brain size is a well-known driver of animal cognition. However, it is not the only one. In this study, we show that the evolution of brain size is not the only driver of cognitive evolution. We show that the evolution of brain size is associated with the evolution of cognitive ability only in a few groups of mammals, including birds and primates. This suggests that the evolution of brain size is not the only driver of cognitive evolution.

The role of TRAP1 in cancer has been controversial. Some studies have shown that TRAP1 is a tumor promoter, whereas others have shown that TRAP1 is a tumor suppressor. Here we show that TRAP1 is a metabolic regulator in cancer cells. We also show that TRAP1 is a tumor suppressor in mouse models of cancer. These data suggest that TRAP1 may be a potential therapeutic target in cancer.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of actin filament dynamics. It is known to sever filaments, but the mechanism by which it does so is not understood. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF binds to filaments and induces severing in a mechanical torque-dependent manner. This mechanism is critical for ADF to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our results provide a mechanistic explanation for how ADF, a small protein, can regulate the dynamics of actin filaments, which are the major cytoskeletal filament network in cells. Our findings also suggest that the mechanical state of the filament network may be an important determinant of the dynamics of the filament network.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in beverages and foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation and greater hunger and desire for food and food-approach behavior. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. The results also suggest that fructose may be a stronger trigger of food-seeking behavior. The findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and food intake. They also suggest that fructose may be a more important contributor to the obesity epidemic than previously thought. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its cultural diversity. It is the only place where Austronesian and Bantu languages are spoken, and it is the only place where the two populations have coexisted for millennia. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, and we found that the Austronesian and Bantu populations are related, but there is also a significant contribution from Southeast Asians. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a sex-biased and geographically heterogeneous way, suggesting that the settlement of Madagascar was a complex process. Finally, we found that the genomic diversity of Madagascar is already structured, suggesting that the settlement of Madagascar happened relatively recently. These results help us to understand the settlement of Madagascar and the origin of its unique cultural diversity.

Emotional contagion is the phenomenon of people experiencing the same emotions as others without their awareness. It is well established in laboratory experiments, but the evidence for it in the real world is controversial. In this experiment, we test whether emotional contagion occurs outside of in-person interaction between individuals by reducing the amount of emotional content in the News Feed. We find that when positive expressions were reduced, people produced fewer positive posts and more negative posts; when negative expressions were reduced, the opposite pattern occurred. These results indicate that emotions expressed by others on Facebook influence our own emotions, constituting experimental evidence for massive-scale contagion via social networks. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. (Abridged)

Messenger RNA (mRNA) is a critical component of the translation machinery, and the sequence of nucleotides in an mRNA can have a profound impact on translation. In this study, we show that the presence of a single pseudouridine (Ψ) in an mRNA codon can have a significant impact on translation. We find that the presence of Ψ can increase the rate of near-cognate aminoacyl tRNA binding to a Ψ codon, and that the presence of Ψ in coding regions can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. These findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can have a significant impact on translation, and that the presence of Ψ in coding regions may be a mechanism by which the ribosome encounters Ψ. Our work provides a better understanding of the impact of mRNA modifications on translation, and may have implications for the design of mRNA therapeutics. (Less)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, social relationships, and use of time. These associations are robust across a wide range of sociodemographic factors, and they are also robust over time. The feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of larger body size is a defining feature of aquatic mammals, but the mechanisms driving this pattern remain unclear. We use a model of energy intake and energy expenditure to show that the evolution of larger body size is a natural consequence of the aquatic environment. Our model predicts that the evolution of larger body size is driven by the aquatic environment and is constrained by the energetic demands of the aquatic environment. These predictions are consistent with the evolution of larger body size in aquatic mammals.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold, and most rhinovirus isolates replicate more robustly at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. The mechanism of temperature-dependent growth is not well understood. Here we show that mouse airway cells infected with rhinovirus exhibit a more efficient antiviral defense response at core body temperature than at cool temperature. This difference in defense response led to higher levels of viral replication at core body temperature. These findings provide insight into the mechanism of temperature-dependent growth and may help to explain why rhinovirus replication is more common in the cold. They also suggest that the antiviral defense response of infected cells may be a potential target for antiviral therapy. (PsycINFO Database Record

Bacteria use a variety of mechanisms to sense their environment, and these mechanisms are often used for multiple purposes. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses type IV pili to sense surfaces, and that this mechanism is used for more than just twitching motility. We demonstrate that type IV pili are used as a mechanochemical sensor to detect mechanical changes in the pili, and that this mechanochemical signal is amplified by a positive feedback loop to regulate surface attachment and virulence. This work provides a mechanistic explanation for how type IV pili are used as a sensor in addition to their primary function of twitching motility, and demonstrates that type IV pili are used for multiple purposes in the same cell. This work also provides a model for how bacteria can use pili as mechanosensitive sensors to regulate their behavior in response to mechanical signals. This work is important because it provides a mechanistic understanding of how bacteria can use pili for multiple purposes, and how pili can be used as mechanosensitive sensors. This work also provides a model for how bacteria can use pili for multiple purposes, and how pili can be used as mechanosensitive sensors.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades, and the use of newer-generation insecticides has increased even more. This study provides the first comprehensive global analysis of the presence of these insecticides in surface waters. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. The results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions. This study is important for the scientific community, policy makers, and the public.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and society. However, the role of animals in the transmission of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, is poorly understood. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to infection. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 can be transmitted between deer. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. Our study highlights the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the role of animals in the spread of COVID-19. (Less)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and climate change. This paper examines the causes of this trend, the problems that are being created, and the solutions that are needed. We find that the benefits of hydropower are overestimated and the costs underestimated. We also find that the environmental and social concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned are not being addressed. We propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder that is characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins in the brain. The exact mechanisms underlying the development of these pathologies are not fully understood, but are believed to be triggered by sustained microglial activation in response to Aβ plaques and cell death. Here, we demonstrate that neurons are also capable of producing potent inflammatory factors, which are released into the extracellular environment and may trigger the immune response. We show that the accumulation of soluble Aβ species within the brain is sufficient to trigger a neuron-specific inflammatory response, which may precede the formation of Aβ plaques and tau tangles. These findings provide a mechanism for the development of the earliest AD-related immune response, and may help to explain the lack of inflammation in the brains of the earliest AD-affected individuals. This may also explain the failure of current treatments to halt the progression of the disease. Thus, our results suggest that the Aβ-burdened neuron may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of AD.

The domestic chicken is today one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still missing. Our faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, provides the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens. We show that the frequency of chicken bones at Maresha is more than 10 times higher than at comparable sites in the Southern Levant and that the ratio of female to male bones is 2:1, which is a clear indication of economic exploitation. Our results suggest that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood in detail. The folding of a large protein is even more difficult to study because of the large amount of material required. We have developed a method that allows the study of the folding of a large protein at high structural resolution. We have used this method to study the folding of maltose binding protein, a large protein that folds in two steps. The first step is a fast collapse into a polyglobular state, which is followed by a slower step that forms a native-like folding intermediate. The intermediate is an obligatory step on the folding pathway and is the site of three destabilizing mutations that slow the folding of the protein. The intermediate is also the site of a second step of folding that is not yet understood. These results add a large protein to the list of proteins known to fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. This list is growing, and it is becoming clear that the folding of large proteins is more complex than previously thought.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. However, the cellular mechanisms that control the concentration of Np4 and the extent to which it affects gene expression are not well understood. Here, we show that the decapping enzyme RppH, which removes the cap of the nucleoside diphosphate (NDP) cap structure, is the predominant enzyme responsible for decapping Np4-capped transcripts in Escherichia coli cells experiencing stress. We also show that RppH prefers to decape Np4-capped transcripts over NDP-capped ones, and that the Np4 cap is recognized by the δ-phosphate rather than the β-phosphate of the NDP cap. These findings provide a mechanistic explanation for how Np4 can regulate gene expression in bacteria.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcome. Although the immune system is activated in response to infection, it can also become dysfunctional, leading to a state of immunosuppression that is associated with poor clinical outcome. We hypothesized that arginine, an essential amino acid, could be used to restore immune function in sepsis. We demonstrated that arginine administration was more efficient than citrulline in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing immunosuppression. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides evidence for the use of citrulline as a therapeutic agent in other diseases in which arginine is depleted. This is an important finding because arginine is a key amino acid in the diet.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is an order of magnitude higher than that of plants. We also highlight the historical impact of humans on the biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to better understand the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in which a dynamical system evolves at a constant rate, without being externally driven, and in which the system’s rate of change is proportional to its current state. SOC is observed in a variety of natural and man-made systems, including earthquakes, sandpiles, fire spreading, neural networks, and financial markets. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, its electronic properties are difficult to control, and its bandgap is difficult to tune. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, solely under mechanical strain, without phonon instability. We also show that diamond can be demetallized, solely under mechanical strain, without phonon instability. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This work also provides a general framework for exploring the relationship between electronic and phonon properties in solids. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The role of plant-associated microorganisms in the health of the host is well established. However, the mechanisms by which these microorganisms protect the host are not fully understood. In this work, we show that a small peptide from the legume nodule microbiome, NCR044, has antifungal activity and can protect plants against fungal pathogens. The antifungal activity of the peptide is unique in that it is not mediated by the classical mode of action of antifungal peptides, i.e., by binding to the fungal cell wall. Instead, the peptide binds to bioactive phosphoinositides in the fungal cell, which leads to disruption of the plasma membrane and subsequent cell death. The peptide also has a structural architecture that is unique among plant antifungal peptides. This work provides a unique example of a plant antifungal peptide with a structural architecture that is not similar to any other known peptide. This work also provides a proof of concept that a small peptide can be used to protect plants against fungal pathogens. This work opens up a new avenue for the development of small peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This is an important step toward the development of sustainable agriculture.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes, and it is likely that the male–female interface is a site of molecular continuity. However, the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is largely unknown. Here, we use proteomics to characterize the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between males and females. We show that the male–female interface is a dynamic one, and that female contributions support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work will be of interest to the broader scientific community and to the public interested in the reproductive system.

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the platelet surface. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD), and the A1 domain in VWF is thought to be the target of these mutations. We show that the A1 domain of VWF can be switched to a second state with faster binding kinetics by force, which is a relevant force in the context of bleeding. This mechanism provides a mechanism for the pathophysiology of VWD mutations. The mechanism is also relevant to the mechanism of action of some drugs that increase the binding of VWF to platelets. The mechanism is also relevant to the mechanism of action of some drugs that increase the binding of VWF to platelets.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the human virome, the set of viruses that live in or on humans, has been difficult to study because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses, which is the largest of its kind. The database is used to show that many viruses are associated with disease, and that the human virome is more complex than previously thought. This study is a major step toward understanding the human microbiome.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in climate models due to the complexity of the process. Observations of ACI are challenging because of the lack of simultaneous observations of aerosols and clouds. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), which can simultaneously measure aerosols and clouds. We demonstrate the capability of this instrument to investigate ACI. The observations show that aerosol loading has no discernible effect on liquid water path but increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This paper is expected to be a significant contribution to the ACI community.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of interest for many years. The temperature of the surface is important because it is the temperature at which life on Earth is most likely to exist. The temperature of the surface is also important because it is the temperature at which enzymes function. The temperature of the surface is therefore important because it is the temperature at which life functions. This paper presents a method for determining the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past. The method is based on the thermostability of enzymes reconstructed from ancient DNA. The results of this study suggest that the temperature of the surface of the Earth has decreased over geological time. This finding is consistent with other lines of evidence and suggests that the temperature of the surface of the Earth has been decreasing over geological time.

Ion channels are important for the normal function of the nervous system and heart. They are also involved in a variety of diseases, including cardiac arrhythmia. Ion channels are composed of protein subunits that form a pore through which ions can flow. The pore is controlled by two gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. We found that the BK channel lacks an intracellular activation gate and normally shows no C-type inactivation. We also found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. Our findings may help us understand the normal function and diseases of ion channels. They may also provide a new approach for the treatment of cardiac arrhythmia. Malaria parasite invasion of the red blood cell (RBC) is a critical step in the disease pathogenesis. The parasite uses a number of adhesins to bind to the RBC surface, but the function of this interaction is unknown. Here, we show that the binding of the malaria parasite erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175) to glycophorin A (GPA) on the RBC surface leads to a change in the biophysical properties of the RBC. Specifically, we show that EBA175 binding to GPA leads to an increase in the cytoskeletal tension and a reduction in the bending modulus of the RBC membrane. These changes in the RBC are correlated with parasite invasion efficiency. This finding suggests that the malaria parasite primes the RBC surface through its binding antigens, altering the biophysical nature of the target cell and thus reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This is a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This work provides a new perspective on the invasion process and opens up new avenues for the development of antimalarial strategies.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, its electronic properties are difficult to control, and its bandgap is difficult to tune. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under mechanical strain, and its bandgap can be tuned continuously. This work provides a new route to control the electronic properties of diamond, and it is expected to be useful for the development of diamond-based devices. This work also provides a new route to control the electronic properties of diamond, and it is expected to be useful for the development of diamond-based devices.

Influenza virus infection is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide mechanistic insights into the impact of low humidity on influenza virus infection and disease outcome. They also suggest that low humidity may be a modifiable risk factor for influenza virus infection. This may be particularly important in the context of climate change. (PsycINFO Database Record

The brain’s processing of language is often assumed to involve a tree-like structure of nested phrases. However, whether and how the brain builds such structures remains largely unknown. Here, we used intracranial recordings to investigate how the brain’s activity varies during the formation of phrase structures. We found that high-gamma power increased with each successive word in a sentence but decreased suddenly whenever words could be merged into a phrase. This merge operation was applied equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity, providing evidence for a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. More superficial models of language, based solely on sequential transition probability over lexical and syntactic categories, only captured activity in the posterior middle temporal gyrus. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This may be a fundamental property of the brain’s language processing system.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates that is involved in many processes, including development and cancer. The pathway is regulated by two scaffolds, Axin1 and Axin2, which are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We show here that differential regulation of the two genes on the transcriptional and proteostatic level confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This work provides a deeper understanding of the mechanisms that regulate redundant genes in vertebrates. It also provides a resource for the study of the mechanisms that regulate redundant genes in general.

Obesity is a major health problem, and the mechanisms that regulate food intake are poorly understood. Here we describe a circuit that may contribute to overeating. We show that electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus induces vigorous eating in sated mice. This effect is blocked by dopamine antagonists, and dopamine lesions or receptor antagonists block the effect. We also show that this circuit is necessary for the effect, as demonstrated by the failure of dopamine lesions to block the effect. This circuit may contribute to overeating in humans. Thus, we present a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. This work may help to elucidate the mechanisms that regulate food intake and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for obesity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to engineer nitrogen fixation in plants would be a major advance in agriculture. Here, we demonstrate the use of a bacterial signal to control nitrogen fixation in a cereal plant. This work represents a major step toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of rhizopine as a synthetic plant-controlled signal. The use of rhizopine as a synthetic plant-controlled signal has the potential to be applied to a wide range of cereal crops. The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest, and its deforestation is a major driver of climate change. Despite substantial investments in remote-sensed forest monitoring, early deforestation alerts rarely reach the most directly affected populations in time to deter deforestation. We study a community monitoring program that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. Our results suggest that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated. The program’s monitors were perceived as new authorities with influence over forest management, and the monitors’ patrols were perceived as substitutes for traditional, unincentivized citizen patrols that inhibit timely detection of and response to deforestation. Should our findings be replicated elsewhere, they imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their hearing to perceive the world around them. The auditory organs of animals are diverse in anatomy, but all are made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is outsourced to its web, which acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna. The spider is able to remotely detect and localize the source of an incoming acoustic wave, such as those emitted by approaching prey or predators, by sensing the motion of its web. The spider supersizes its auditory surface area by outsourcing and regenerating its web, which provides unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. This study provides insights into the evolution of hearing and the outsourcing of sensory functions in general. It also provides a unique model system for studying the sensing and manipulation of acoustic flows.

The health and climate impacts of air pollution and greenhouse gases are difficult to disentangle. We show that removing fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources can save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. The health benefits are greatest in the most populous regions of the world, where the largest reductions of air pollution are needed. The climate benefits are greatest in the most densely populated regions of the world, where the largest reductions of greenhouse gases are needed. The combination of these two types of benefits is likely to be the most effective in terms of saving lives and limiting global warming.

COVID-19 is a global pandemic that has resulted in over 5 million deaths worldwide. The lack of a global vaccine supply has led to a patchwork of vaccine availability, with many countries unable to access vaccines. We report a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein that is well-suited for inclusion in a vaccine. This variant exhibits high-affinity binding to the human ACE2 receptor, and antibodies raised against the variant protein exhibit heterotypic binding to the RBD from two variants of concern. Presentation of the variant on a virus-like particle also reduced weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. This variant is a potential candidate for inclusion in a vaccine to address the global COVID-19 pandemic. This work is a step toward a global vaccine supply that can be deployed to address the pandemic.

The role of ALK in human cancer has been established by the discovery of ALK mutations in neuroblastoma. In this study, we show that zebrafish ALK/Ltk signaling is required for the development of iridophores, neural crest-derived pigment cells. We also show that zebrafish ALKALs are able to activate zebrafish Ltk and human ALK. Our results provide in vivo evidence of (i) activation of ALK/LTK family receptors by ALKALs and (ii) an involvement of these ligand–receptor complexes in neural crest development. Our findings may help to understand the role of ALK in human cancer and to identify new therapeutic targets in neuroblastoma. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The emergence of plague as a devastating disease in humans is a well-known historical event, but the details of its origins are still debated. Here, we present a large dataset of ancient Yersinia pestis genomes from Eurasia, which allowed us to explore the diversity of this pathogen during the formative years of its evolution. Our results show that the Y. pestis lineage that gave rise to the plague we know today was already present in Europe and the Near East by 5,000 y BP, and that the flea-adapted form of plague was already present in Europe by 3,000 y BP. These data provide a more complete picture of the origins of plague and its relationship with its vector, the flea. They also provide a unique resource for studying the evolution of plague in the past. (Less)

The endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—is associated with men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump. This work highlights the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The findings have implications for understanding the political climate in the United States and the role of masculinity in the 2020 presidential election. The findings also have implications for understanding the role of masculinity in the gender gap in support for Trump. The findings have implications for understanding the role of masculinity in the gender gap in support for Trump.

The agricultural use of grasslands has been shown to be a major driver of soil carbon loss to the atmosphere. However, the effects of soil health management practices on soil carbon storage in these systems are highly uncertain. We show that soil health management practices that reduce soil disturbance, diversify crop rotations, and integrate livestock can increase soil carbon storage in grasslands. These results highlight the potential of grasslands to sequester carbon and provide a valuable opportunity to mitigate climate change while maintaining the productivity of agricultural lands. This study also highlights the importance of long-term field experiments in assessing the effects of management on soil carbon storage. This approach is critical to understanding the role of agricultural lands in climate change mitigation and to developing strategies for sustainable agricultural production.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of novel viruses from wildlife to humans. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spill over and cause outbreaks in humans. We used this framework to identify the top 12 wildlife viruses with the greatest spillover potential. The SpillOver platform is a living database that can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This work is a step toward a better understanding of the risk of spillover of novel viruses from wildlife to humans and the development of strategies to prevent and control future outbreaks.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. The color of nectar is often used as an indicator of the type of pollinator attracted to the plant. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We demonstrate that this compound is attractive to the vertebrate pollinator, Phelsuma geckos, and that this trait is likely to be favored by selection. This work provides evidence that the red color of nectar is a widespread and convergently evolved trait in nectar-feeding vertebrates. This finding suggests that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. Our results also highlight the importance of alkaloids in the evolution of vertebrate pollination.

The genetic history of Europe during the period of the Migration Period (5th–8th centuries AD) is poorly understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who died mostly between 470 and 670 AD. Our data indicate that the genetic ancestry of men from this period is similar to that of modern northern and central Europeans, while women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity, including signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. This heterogeneity is also reflected in the collective genetic ancestry of the group of women with artificial skull deformations, who had a genetic origin in southeastern Europe. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. Our results provide insights into the demographic processes that occurred during this period and the genetic consequences for modern Europeans.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe human pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings provide insights into the origin of MERS-CoV and the evolution of its receptor and host range. They also provide a basis for the development of vaccines

The global spread of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens is a major public health concern. In resource-scarce settings, where laboratory diagnostics and bioinformatics capacity are limited, the ability to rapidly identify pathogens is critical for effective public health response. We describe the use of metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) to investigate undifferentiated febrile illness in a periurban population in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers. Our findings highlight the importance of mNGS in resource-scarce settings and the need for coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance. This approach can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This study demonstrates the feasibility of mNGS pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings.
