The human genome is replicated in the nucleus by the DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) holoenzyme, which is anchored to the proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) sliding clamp. The stability of this complex is integral to every aspect of replication. We developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Our results indicate that the pol δ holoenzyme is loosely associated with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This work provides a unique perspective on the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme and the mechanisms that regulate its activity during DNA replication. It also provides a foundation for future studies on the role of the pol δ holoenzyme in human diseases.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, RNA molecules can be used to direct the activity of ribozymes, but it has not been possible to use ribozymes to synthesize functional RNA molecules. Here, we describe the development of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and tRNA. This RNA polymerase ribozyme can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work represents a major step toward the reconstruction of RNA-based life.

Urban change is a central topic in urban studies. In this paper, we introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods is a key factor in the success of cities. This work is an important step toward understanding the physical mechanisms of urban change.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is complex, and the treatment is still in the stage of trial and error. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathways, is effective in severe and critical COVID-19 patients. The results provide a reference for the treatment of COVID-19.

Frost is a major environmental stressor that affects the performance of plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. Despite its ecological and economic impact, the geographic distribution and evolutionary impact of frost events are poorly understood. We use a large dataset of leaf-out dates and leaf-freezing resistance of woody species to infer their frost resistance strategies and forecast forest vulnerability under the ongoing changes in frost frequencies. Our findings reveal region-specific changes in the spring-frost risk that can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy. Our results also highlight the importance of studying the evolutionary impact of frost events on species’ resistance strategies. This study is a step toward a better understanding of the impact of climate change on the world’s forests.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, it is unclear whether these cells are required for disease or are merely a component of the inflammatory response. Here, we show that Th17 cells are required for the development of colitis and that they can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results suggest that Th17 cells are important mediators of inflammatory bowel disease pathogenesis.

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of Anaplasma phagocytophilum, the causative agent of human granulocytic anaplasmosis. We now show that Anaplasma modifies the tick microbiota to enhance its transmission. We demonstrate that Anaplasma induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the composition of the gut microbiota and the integrity of the peritrophic matrix. These data reveal a mechanism by which a human pathogen manipulates the gut microbiota of its vector to enhance transmission. This work also highlights the importance of the gut microbiota in the transmission of vector-borne pathogens. (Less)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the evolution of birds. The short-tailed bird group is a major evolutionary lineage that is critical for understanding the origin of the modern avian bauplan. However, the currently limited known diversity of early branching short-tailed birds obscures our understanding of this major transition in avian evolution. Here, we describe a basal short-tailed bird, Jinguofortis perplexus, that adds important information about early members of the short-tailed bird group. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal short-tailed birds and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds. This study also provides important information about the origin of the avian tail and the evolution of mosaic evolution in birds.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand its behavior. One way to make progress is to understand the role of individual processes. Here we show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, due to the presence of pigments in their tissues. In some species, the presence of high concentrations of biliverdin, a pigment that is normally present in the blood, causes the tissues to appear blue-green. This phenomenon is called chlorosis. We show that chlorosis has evolved multiple times during the evolutionary history of anurans, and that the mechanism is the same—the presence of a group of proteins that bind biliverdin. These proteins are most similar to human antiproteases, but with a remarkable functional diversification. Our results provide evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. The Bible was the first book to be printed, and the first printed books were pocket Bibles. The parchment used to make these books was so thin that it was difficult to identify the source of the animal skin used to make it. Here, we describe a method that allows us to identify the animal species used to make parchment. We found that the Bible parchment was made from more than one species of animal, suggesting that the process of making parchment was more complex than previously thought. This method could be used to identify the source of the animal skins used to make parchment in the past and could be used to identify the source of the animal skins used in the production of modern books.

The Permian-Triassic extinction is the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is controversial, but the evidence points to a global environmental perturbation. The age model for the extinction is critical for understanding the timing of the perturbation and its impact on the biosphere. The age model presented here is based on the precise dating of volcanic ash beds that mark the Permian-Triassic boundary. The age model is consistent with the carbon cycle perturbation and provides a precise time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. The age model will also be critical for evaluating the timing of ecosystem recovery.

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a group of chronic inflammatory diseases of the gastrointestinal tract, which is characterized by the overactivation of the immune system. The pathogenesis of IBD is complex and multifactorial, and the treatment is still challenging. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORα deletion leads to excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Our study provides a potential therapeutic target for IBD. This study also provides a new perspective for the treatment of IBD. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the immune response of the host. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the receptor ACE2 at 3.0-Å resolution. The structure of the spike in complex with ACE2 shows that the D614G mutation has little effect on the overall structure of the spike. However, the D614G mutation does affect the conformational flexibility of the spike, which may facilitate receptor binding. Our results provide a structural basis for the observed increase in infectivity of the D614G mutant.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that, in the absence of the pandemic, life expectancy at birth would have been 78.65 y in 2020, a decline of 1.13 y, and at age 65 y, 83.33 y, a decline of 0.87 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006.

The chemical properties of an element are its most important properties, and they are the basis of all chemistry. The chemical properties of an element are determined by the energy required to remove an electron from the atom, which is the chemical potential of the electron in the atom. We show that the chemical potential of the electron in an atom decreases with pressure, and we propose a modified chemical potential of the electron, which we call electronegativity, as a measure of the chemical potential of the electron in an atom. We also show that the chemical hardness of an atom decreases with pressure, and we propose a modified chemical hardness as a measure of the chemical hardness of an atom. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales.

Climate change is expected to increase fire activity in some regions and decrease it in others. However, the net effect on global carbon emissions is not clear. We show that human ignitions and suppression can have a large effect on fire activity, and that these effects can offset or amplify climate change. We find that climate–carbon cycle feedbacks are most effective at slowing global warming under lower emission scenarios. Our study highlights that ignitions and suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate, although with some risk of more extreme fires regionally and with implications for other ecosystem functions in fire-dependent ecosystems. Our results have implications for climate change mitigation and adaptation, and for the design of fire management strategies. They also highlight the need for more research on the role of ignitions and suppression in future fire regimes.

The mutualism between symbiotic bacteria and their animal hosts is one of the most common forms of life on Earth. The symbionts of these associations are often associated with the epithelial cells of the host, where they can have a major impact on the host’s physiology. In this study, we show that the bacteria can regulate their own persistence in the epithelial cells by the strategic provision of a single glycan. This glycan is synthesized by the host, and its provision to the bacteria is synchronized with the host’s circadian rhythm. This glycan is catabolized by the bacteria, which is required for the acidification of the epithelial cells, which in turn enhances the bacteria’s ability to produce light. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of symbiosis by the provision of nutrients. It also highlights the importance of glycans in the regulation of the symbiosis.

The study of topics in text is a fundamental problem in natural language processing. We introduce a method that integrates advances in theoretical machine learning with word embedding to model topics in text. Our method, discourse atom topic modeling, is motivated by the need to model the structure of text, and it is applicable to a wide range of domains. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text. We believe that this method will be useful to many researchers in the field.

The Black Death, which occurred in the 14th century, is the most devastating epidemic in human history. It is generally assumed that the bacterium Yersinia pestis was introduced into Europe via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. However, this assumption is based on a single hypothesis, which has not been tested. We show that the climate conditions in Asia and Europe were very similar in the years preceding the first plague outbreaks in Europe, and that the first plague introductions into Europe were delayed by 15 ± 1 y. These findings suggest that the bacterium was introduced into Europe via a different route.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important for the functioning of marine ecosystems. They are also a major source of food for sea stars, which are important predators in marine ecosystems. In the Northeast Pacific, asteroids are currently experiencing a mass mortality event that is associated with a densovirus. This is the first report of a densovirus associated with a mass mortality event in asteroids. The virus is likely to be an important factor in the decline of this important component of the marine ecosystem.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a devastating disease with a poor prognosis. The identification of targets for therapy is therefore of great importance. In this study, we show that the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We demonstrate that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. Furthermore, we show that an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling can also suppress the proliferation of primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. The results also suggest that IL-1 signaling may be important for the growth of AML cells. Thus, the results may also be relevant for the treatment of other diseases in which IL-1 signaling is important.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its cultural diversity. It is the only place where the Austronesian language family, which includes the languages of the Pacific islands, is spoken in its original form. The island is also a unique case in terms of its settlement history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar and found that the Austronesian and Bantu populations are the only ones that are present on the island. The settlement history of Madagascar is also unique, as it is the only case where the population growth happened recently, and the population was not already admixed. These results are important for understanding the settlement history of Madagascar and the origin of the Austronesian language family. They also provide a unique opportunity to study the impact of the human population on the island.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that increases the activity of aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase. We found that the protein interferes with the ability of the RNA to repress genes involved in carbon utilization. This demonstrates that the protein and RNA compete for the same binding sites on the genome. This is an example of a dual-function RNA that has evolved to regulate multiple biological processes.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may help to address the challenge of SARS-CoV-2 variants and the need for new antibody drug candidates. Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in many countries. However, their data are often not used in agricultural decision-making because it is difficult to integrate it with other sources of information. We show that the Crop Progress and Condition (CPC) survey, which is the main source of information on crop status in the United States, is a rich source of information that can be used to build quantitative models of crop status. We show that these models are robust across different crops, exhibit long-term stability, and have nation-wide validity. We also show how to transform the original qualitative data into a continuous, probabilistic variable better suited to quantitative analysis. Finally, we demonstrate how this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. This work provides a framework for the use of crop expert data in agricultural decision-making.

Language processing is a complex cognitive task that involves the ability to integrate and store information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism that supports this process. Information is stored in the form of changes in the excitability of neuronal populations. These changes are adaptive, meaning that they are dependent on the history of the system. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is one of the most important evolutionary events in the history of life. It is associated with a massive reduction in the number of genes and the functional complexity of plastids, the organelles that are responsible for the majority of the plant’s metabolic functions. Here, we present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition is associated with a gradual relaxation of purifying selection on plastid genes, which is linked to the establishment of the parasitic lifestyle. Our findings provide a framework for understanding the molecular evolution of plastids and their genes during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. They also provide a model for the evolution of other organelles that are involved in the process of horizontal gene transfer.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark example of the impact of climate change on water resources in South Africa. We use a high-resolution climate model to show that anthropogenic climate change increased the probability of the 2015–2017 drought by a factor of five to six. This increase is likely to be even larger under a high-emission scenario. The results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This study also shows that the drought risk in SSA is highly sensitive to the spatial pattern of rainfall variability, which is difficult to capture with current climate models. This highlights the need for a better understanding of the role of natural variability in the context of anthropogenic climate change. This will be critical for the development of drought risk management strategies in SSA. (Abridged)

The discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear explosion, the “Trinity test,” in 1945, was a seminal event in the history of science. It led to the discovery of the first quasicrystal in nature, in the Khatyrka meteorite, and to the realization that quasicrystals are a new class of crystalline solids. Here, we report the discovery of a second, anthropogenic quasicrystal in red trinitite, the first example of this class of materials to be found in the archaeological record. The discovery of this material, which is a member of a new quasicrystal-forming system, provides a unique link between the discovery of the first quasicrystal in nature and the first test explosion of a nuclear weapon.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the pathway, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use an O2-sensitive [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess an O2-dependent enzyme, the major catalytic component of which is a diiron protein. Here, we show that the O2-dependent enzyme is composed of three classes, and that the cyanobacterial enzyme requires a subunit that we term Ycf54. These data delineate three classes of O2-dependent cyclase in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants to bacteria, and their evolution is discussed herein.

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1, which is known to be involved in the regulation of neuroinflammation. However, the precise cellular and molecular mechanisms of ASK1 in neuroinflammation remain unknown. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the generation and maintenance of neuroinflammation. In addition, ASK1 in astrocytes plays a critical role in the later stage of neuroinflammation. These findings suggest that ASK1 in glial cells may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. Our study provides a better understanding of the roles of ASK1 in neuroinflammation and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for neurodegenerative diseases. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is attributable to human activities. We also find that the probability of drought years is more than doubled if precipitation deficits occur when conditions are warm. These findings suggest that anthropogenic warming has increased the probability of co-occurring warm and dry conditions in California. This conclusion is supported by a large ensemble of climate model experiments, which shows that human activities have increased the probability of warm–dry conditions. The results also suggest that the probability of drought years will continue to increase in the future. Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder that is caused by the interaction of multiple genetic factors and environmental factors. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. The store-operated Ca2+ (SO) channel is a key regulator of cellular functions, including gene expression, cell growth and differentiation, and Ca2+ homeostasis. Mutations in the pore-forming protein of the SO channel, ORAI1, or in the Ca2+ sensor STIM1, result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1, associated with a Stormorken syndrome of hematological abnormalities, and in ORAI1, associated with a Stormorken-like syndrome of hematological abnormalities and tubular myopathy. The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease and several forms of frontotemporal dementia. In these diseases, the spread of aggregates is thought to be a major contributor to the progressive loss of neurons in the brain. Here we use a fluorescently tagged polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to study the spread of aggregates in a model of Huntington’s disease. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and spread throughout the brain, where they are internalized and accumulate within other neurons. We also show that the spread of aggregates is non–cell-autonomous and that the loss of vulnerable neurons can be prevented by inhibiting endocytosis in these neurons. Finally, we show that the release of aggregates requires N-ethylmalemide–sensitive fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. Cancer cells have a number of metabolic adaptations that allow them to survive despite the presence of a tumor. One such metabolic adaptation is the ability to use serine as a one-carbon donor, which is required for the synthesis of purine nucleotides. This study identifies a small-molecule inhibitor of serine hydroxymethyltransferase, a key enzyme in this pathway, and shows that it blocks colon cancer growth in mice. This strategy could be extended to other cancers that use serine as a one-carbon donor. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease that is caused by mutations in a number of proteins. These proteins, including SOD1, TDP-43, and FUS, are highly aggregation-prone and form intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Instead, we observe that the inclusion bodies in ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results suggest that the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in ALS results from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The photonic crystals can be used to control the interactions between atoms, which can be used to study the properties of quantum many-body systems. The photonic crystals can also be used to control the emission of light from atoms, which can be used to study the properties of quantum emitters. The photonic crystals can be used in many other applications, such as quantum information processing, quantum simulation, and quantum sensing.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the evolution of the plant kingdom. The first flowering plants were aquatic plants that colonized the surface of the water. The study of the aquatic flowering plants of the Cretaceous period is of great interest because it opens the possibility that aquatic plants were common at an early stage of the evolution of the flowering plants. The study of Montsechia, a Cretaceous aquatic flowering plant, is presented here.

The human parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous pathogen that has been associated with a number of conditions, including fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes from dental and skeletal remains of individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and we are able to date the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 thousand years ago. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. Sea level is a key indicator of global climate change because it is rising at a rate that is unprecedented in modern history. In this study, we use satellite altimeter data to estimate the rate of sea level rise over the last 25 y and find that it is accelerating. This acceleration is consistent with the rate of acceleration of global mean temperature rise over the same period. Our results suggest that the rate of sea level rise will continue to accelerate in the future, and that the rate of rise by 2100 could be as high as 15 cm/y.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, pain prevalence has increased with each successive birth cohort, and that this increase is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity. Instead, it is consistent with the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If this trend continues, tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of enzymology. The use of NMR spectroscopy to characterize the structure and dynamics of enzyme active sites has been a powerful tool in this endeavor. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed, chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of the structure and dynamics of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate. This integrated approach provides insight into the structure and dynamics of the enzyme–substrate complex, the role of the cofactor in the reaction, and the role of the enzyme in the reaction. This work highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography as a tool for mechanistic enzymology.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus that has a high case fatality rate. There is no licensed antiviral treatment for MERS, and the only treatment options are supportive care. Here, we show that remdesivir, an investigational broad-spectrum antiviral drug, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for MERS, and also suggests that remdesivir may be effective against other coronaviruses. This is an important step toward the development of a treatment for MERS. The data presented here may also be relevant for the emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. The mutualism between symbiotic bacteria and their animal hosts is one of the most common forms of life on Earth. The symbionts of these associations are often associated with the epithelial cells of the host, where they can influence the host’s physiology and behavior. In this study, we show that the bacteria can also influence the host’s behavior by the strategic provision of a single glycan. This glycan is provided to the epithelial cells only at night, when the bacteria are most active. The glycan is catabolized by the bacteria, which in turn influences the host’s behavior. This is an example of how the symbionts of animals can influence their hosts’ behavior through the strategic provision of nutrients. Suspension rates in US schools have risen sharply in recent decades, with disproportionate effects on students of color and students with disabilities. This study shows that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed, and that this change can have a positive impact on students’ behavior and well-being. The study also shows that a scalable intervention can reduce suspension rates in schools. These findings have implications for the future of US schools.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotically transmitted pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To better understand how sequential proteolysis contributes to MERS-CoV infection, we introduced mutations that blocked the first cleavages of MERS-CoV spike (S) proteins. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection, but had little effect on infection into other cell types. These findings suggest that the first cleavages of S proteins are important for MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

In this study, we show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a large university cafeteria led to a proportional increase in vegetarian meal sales of 61.8% and that the effect was concentrated among diners with the lowest levels of vegetarian meal selection in the population. These findings suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering outlets could be a powerful way to promote more sustainable diets at the population level. This approach could be used to complement other interventions, such as increasing the price of meat. The cell surface proteome is a dynamic interface for the extracellular space, and is a potential target for cancer therapy. Here we use quantitative proteomics to show how the surfaceome is remodeled in a panel of isogenic breast epithelial cells stably expressing six of the most prominent oncogenes, including EGFR, HER2, KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a step toward understanding the role of the cell surface in cancer biology and drug discovery. The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We use a difference-in-differences design to estimate the effects of vote-by-mail on turnout, vote share, and overall turnout rates. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. They also suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that can be implemented with little cost and with minimal risk of electoral fraud. They provide a strong rationale for expanding vote-by-mail programs in the United States.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has highlighted the need for a rapid understanding of the molecular basis of the disease it causes. Here, we report the structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, a rapidly evolving accessory protein that has been proposed to interfere with immune responses. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion. This work provides a molecular basis for understanding the unique properties of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein and its role in the disease it causes. It also provides a structural reference point for monitoring the evolution of the protein. This will be important for understanding the impact of mutations on the structure and function of the protein and for monitoring the impact of vaccine and therapeutic interventions.

Cerebral edema is a potentially life-threatening condition, and knowledge of its underlying mechanisms is limited. Here we report that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is associated with increased expression of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. We also show that, in cultured primary astrocytes, hypobaric hypoxia triggers cortical release of CRF, which acts on CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of AQP4 and cerebral edema. These findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the pathogenesis of cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. The scientific method is based on the idea that we can learn from experience. This is a powerful idea, but it is not without its challenges. In particular, we must be able to assess the strength of the evidence that we have for a particular conclusion. This is especially important in the era of big data, where we can search for associations in very large datasets. We describe some recent developments in selective inference, which allows us to set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we find.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step in the development of vascular networks. In this study, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) can directly induce the formation of functional vascular ECs (ETVECs) from human fibroblasts. ETV2-induced ETVECs exhibit EC characteristics in vitro and form mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in mice. These findings provide a useful tool for the study of human EC development and the treatment of vascular disorders. Furthermore, the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This study also demonstrates the potential of ETV2 as a therapeutic target for vascular disorders. The receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) are important signaling molecules that are involved in a wide range of physiological processes. In the last few years, two new ligands for RTKs were discovered, which are named ALKAL1 and ALKAL2. These ligands are important for the development of the zebrafish eye and the zebrafish pigment pattern. Here, we show that these ligands are important for the development of the zebrafish pigment pattern and that they are activated by the RTKs. This study provides a link between the RTKs and their ligands and demonstrates that the ligands are important for the development of the zebrafish pigment pattern. This study also provides a model system for the study of the physiological role of RTKs and their ligands.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. Accumulating evidence indicates that STING plays an important role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity. However, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency impaired β-cell function, leading to glucose intolerance. These data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. This study also provides a potential therapeutic target for T2D. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. They are packaged into virions, which are released from infected cells and spread the virus to other cells. The packaging of the viral genome into virions is a highly conserved process, but the molecular details of this process are still unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results provide a molecular explanation for the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome. They also suggest that this interaction might be a target for antiviral drugs. Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is associated with a variety of risk factors, such as hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and diabetes. The underlying mechanisms of atherogenesis are not fully understood. In this study, we found that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) is important for the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesions. Our results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising therapeutic strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis. This study also provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesions. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of atherosclerosis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Wildfire is a natural process that has shaped the landscape of the United States for millennia. However, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades, and climate change has likely contributed to this increase. In this study, we show that humans have vastly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States, and that this expansion is not due to climate change. We recommend that efforts to reduce wildfire risk should focus on reducing the role of humans in starting wildfires.

Urban change is a central topic in urban studies. In this paper, we use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We then connect these changes with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and its proximity to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also highlight the importance of the physical environment in shaping the economic and demographic characteristics of neighborhoods. This work is an important step toward understanding the physical mechanisms of urban change. It also provides a new tool for urban planners and geographers to monitor the physical changes in their cities. Finally, it provides a new way to study the spatial distribution of human capital and the spatial distribution of wealth.

Natural repellents are a sustainable alternative to chemical pesticides, but their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and should help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help the understanding of arthropod–plant adaptation. This study is also important for the conservation of biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Zika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito-borne flavivirus that has recently emerged as a cause of severe neurological complications. The recent outbreak has prompted global concern, and there is an urgent need to understand the mechanisms of ZIKV infection and to develop effective antiviral treatments. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the rate of viral production is rapid, and that the time between cell infection and viral production is short. We also show that antiviral treatments can be effective in reducing the duration of viremia. These results can be used to guide the design of antiviral treatments for ZIKV. (Less)

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that is often used as a proxy for the health of coral reefs. However, the underlying causes of bleaching are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. We demonstrate that the metabolic energy demand of the coral host is increased, which is compensated by the degradation of amino acids. This shift from net uptake to release of ammonium by the coral holobiont subsequently promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a complex ecosystem of commensals and immune cells that protects the host from infections and regulates nutrient absorption. In the context of cancer, the intestinal epithelium loses its barrier function, leading to systemic infections and death. Here, we show that the intestinal microbiome can trigger a regenerative response in the tumor-bearing epithelium, restoring barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our findings may help in the development of therapeutic strategies to control the activity of the intestinal microbiome in cancer patients. They may also provide a model for studying the role of the microbiome in regenerative processes. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Although the majority of breast cancers are estrogen receptor-positive, a small fraction of these tumors are resistant to endocrine therapy. These “treatment-resistant” tumors are enriched for cancer stem cells, which have an enhanced capacity for self-renewal, tumor initiation, and/or metastasis. Here we show that the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 is expressed in such “treatment-resistant” breast cancers. We also show that the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab can reduce the expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, inhibit the growth of breast cancer patient-derived xenografts, and improve the efficacy of chemotherapy in mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (PsycINFO Database Record

The start of accelerated deglaciation of the Southern Hemisphere is often attributed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies and subsequent climate impacts. We show that the start of this event is coincident with the eruption of Mount Takahe, a small volcano in West Antarctica, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion. This unique volcanic event is the only known event that could have caused the changes in climate and circulation that are consistent with the start of accelerated deglaciation.

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but their importance is often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries are a critical source of animal protein for the world’s poorest people. However, the high dependence of poor people on inland fisheries makes them vulnerable to the impacts of poverty and environmental degradation. Our results highlight the need for improved management of inland fisheries to protect biodiversity and food security. Our data can be used to identify areas where inland fisheries are most important for local communities and where conservation efforts should focus. This information can be used to inform environmental planning and decision-making to protect both biodiversity and food security.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable Mo-based oxide is designed to deliver a large capacity and low potential without triggering decomposition of water. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are largely incapable of regenerating after injury. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This DLK-independent regeneration is triggered by physical lesion of a sensory dendrite, and it is enhanced by disrupting neuronal activity and elevating cAMP levels. These findings suggest that DLK-independent regeneration is a powerful platform for gene discovery in the regeneration of the adult mammalian CNS. Moreover, our study suggests that the adult mammalian CNS is capable of regenerating after injury, and it is possible that this form of regeneration could be used to restore function in the adult CNS after injury.

The process of recombination is fundamental to the evolution of genomes and the diversity of life. In this study, we use a population of wild monkeyflowers to precisely locate the locations of hotspots of recombination in a flowering plant. We find that hotspots are distributed throughout the genome, with some interspersed among cold regions of low recombination. The distribution of hotspots is similar to that observed in yeast and in mice, suggesting that the general pattern of recombination initiation in flowering plants may be conserved across eukaryotic evolution.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, in which the activity of a small fraction of neurons is sufficient to generate the observed fluctuations in the magnetic field of the surrounding tissue. The analysis of these fluctuations has led to the identification of a set of reproducible networks, which are assumed to reflect the organization of the brain in health and disease. Here, we used metabolic positron emission tomography to identify and validate the dominant resting state network in healthy subjects and in Parkinson’s disease patients. We found that the dominant network was topographically similar to the default mode network, but that the subordinate networks were associated with disease-related patterns. The dominant network was deactivated during task performance, whereas the subordinate networks were activated. These results provide a direct measure of the organization of the brain in health and disease. They also provide a basis for the development of new imaging techniques that can be used to monitor the organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is essential for translation initiation and is found on all mRNAs in eukaryotes. Here we describe a second 5′ modification, the nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) RNA, which is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. We show that NAD-mRNA is produced cotranscriptionally, and that only on mitochondrial transcripts that are not 5′ end processed. This 5′ NAD+ cap structure raises the possibility that it could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. The discovery of this second cap structure in eukaryotes may have implications for the evolution of the 5′ cap structure and for the regulation of gene expression in eukaryotes.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. The mechanisms underlying metabolic memory are not fully understood. Here we show that epigenetic DNA methylation alterations at specific loci in blood cells from people with diabetes are associated with glycemia for several years during the follow-up of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT). These epigenetic alterations are also associated with metabolic memory. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. They also suggest that epigenetic alterations at specific loci may be used as biomarkers of metabolic memory. This may help to identify people with diabetes who are likely to benefit from intensive therapy. This would be of great importance for the prevention of microvascular complications. The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals that contribute to the overall aroma. Among these volatiles are several aromatic and aliphatic nitrogenous compounds, which are known to be important for tomato flavor. However, the biosynthetic pathways of these compounds are not known. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also show that this gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations to produce these compounds. This work is a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor and will be useful for the improvement of tomato flavor quality. This article is protected by copyright. Biodiversity loss and environmental warming are two of the most profound threats to the functional integrity of the Earth’s ecosystems. However, these factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we use high-throughput experiments to investigate how changes in temperature affect the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. We found that changes in temperature systematically altered the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures departed from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increased, meaning that more species were required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have important implications for our ability to predict the impacts of climate change on ecosystem functioning. They also highlight the need to consider the potential for synergistic effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning. This is critical for the design of effective conservation and management strategies.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation, and its neurons are organized into distinct cell types that are thought to correspond to different aspects of space. However, the anatomical organization of these cell types is not well understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice, and we found that grid cells, which are thought to be responsible for the formation of a map of local space, are anatomically distinct from other cell types. These data suggest that grid cells might have a different organization from other cell types in MEC. This study provides a detailed view of the organization of neurons in MEC and their functional roles in navigation. It also provides a method that can be used to study the organization of neurons in other brain areas. This method will be useful for understanding the organization of the brain.

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a variety of factors, including environmental cues, such as day length. Dodder is a parasitic plant that is able to synchronize its flowering with that of its host. This study shows that the flowering of the host is required for the flowering of the dodder. This is an example of how a parasite may use its own flowering to synchronize its own reproduction with that of its host.

The dopamine-containing nigral system is a critical component of the brain’s reward and motivation circuitry. Here, we describe a previously unrecognized type of arborization of striosomal neurons that targets dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their nigral cell bodies. These clustered cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, these striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. This study provides a unique example of the power of expansion microscopy to reveal previously unrecognized cellular and molecular features of the brain. It also highlights the importance of the dopamine system in health and disease. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We all have a sense of when we feel connected to others, but how do we know when two people are connected? We asked people to talk with each other and rated their felt connection. We found that the speed at which people responded to each other was a robust predictor of felt connection. People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. It is composed of specialized cells that are responsible for generating the electrical impulse that initiates each heartbeat. These cells are located in the heart’s wall and are responsible for maintaining a regular heart rate. In this study, we found that the calcium sensors STIM1 and Orai1 are expressed in the specialized cells of the SAN. We also found that STIM1 regulates the calcium dynamics of these cells, which in turn regulates the heart rate. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms that regulate the heart rate and the function of the SAN. This information could be used to develop new treatments for heart failure. Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well understood. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si priming of JA-mediated defense responses involves priming of JA biosynthesis and accumulation of Si in leaves, and that Si may promote Si accumulation by JA. These findings provide insights into the role of Si in plant defense against insect herbivores. (Abridged)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, an enzyme that is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We demonstrate that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activation of macrophages and that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is a key regulator of ether lipid metabolism in macrophages. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of macrophages and suggest that modulation of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. This study provides a better understanding of the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism and opens the way for the development of new therapeutic strategies for diseases caused by defects in tetrahydrobiopterin biosynthesis. Language is a uniquely human ability that involves the ability to integrate and store information over time. The brain mechanisms underlying this ability are not well understood. Here we propose a computational model of memory that is based on the adaptive changes in neuronal excitability that occur during normal activity. We show that these changes in excitability can be used to store information in a manner that is sensitive to context and serial order. This mechanism is based on the dynamic properties of the neuron rather than on persistent activity or synaptic plasticity. It is therefore more efficient and less energy consuming than alternative proposals. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Plants are sessile organisms that are dependent on external inputs for their growth and development. One of the major challenges in plant biology is the delivery of biomolecules to plants, which is a prerequisite for many biological processes. Here, we report the delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the siRNA-carrying DNA nanostructures determine the internalization efficiency and corresponding gene silencing efficiency. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will be useful for the plant biology community and will help in the delivery of biomolecules to plants for various biological processes.

Nutrient inputs from small tributaries are often overlooked in assessments of watershed nutrient loading. However, we show that small watersheds can be important sources of nutrients to coastal areas. We found that the 6 largest of 235 tributaries accounted for ∼70% of the daily nutrient loads delivered to Lake Michigan. However, small watersheds exhibited nutrient loads that were high for their size and biased toward dissolved inorganic forms. This suggests that nutrients from small watersheds may be more bioavailable and thus more likely to fuel algal blooms in coastal areas. Our findings highlight the importance of small watersheds in coastal eutrophication and the need to address them in nutrient management efforts. This is especially important for large lakes, which are particularly vulnerable to coastal eutrophication.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a mechanical system that is biased toward rare combinations of displacements. We show that this behavior is a consequence of the underlying network structure, and we discuss the implications of our results for the design of catalytic systems.

The mechanisms underlying the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients with autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that the presence of an antibody against the NMDA receptor can change the intrinsic properties of the brain, leading to changes in the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. We use a dynamic causal model to identify the key synaptic parameters that best explain the EEG abnormalities in patients with NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. Finally, we show that these changes in the brain’s intrinsic properties can lead to overt EEG paroxysms when the same parameter fluctuations are tolerated in a model of the control condition. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Ab. They also suggest that the presence of an antibody against the NMDA receptor may be a useful biomarker for the diagnosis of autoimmune encephalitis. This may help to improve the clinical management of patients with this condition. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid climate change, which is unprecedented in the last 2 million years. The cause of this change is still debated, but it is widely accepted that the increase in atmospheric CO2 is one of the main drivers. However, the impact of this increase on the Earth system is still poorly understood. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt climate change that occurred during a glacial period and was driven by an increase in atmospheric CO2. We show that this change was accompanied by a decrease in biodiversity and a massive injection of organic matter into the ocean.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia, the world’s largest producer of palm oil. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results highlight the importance of certification in forested regions and the need for certification to be tightly linked to the effective conservation of biodiversity and climate change mitigation. These findings are important for the future of sustainability certification in the palm oil sector and beyond.

The exocytosis process is tightly regulated in both plants and animals. In this study, we discovered a small molecule that inhibits the exocytosis process in plants and animals. Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the sex of an organism is often a key determinant of its phenotype and behavior. In many vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, resulting in two sexes and two sexes only. However, in some species, multiple sex determination alleles are segregating within a single species, allowing for more than two genotypic sexes. Here we investigate the effects of multiple alleles on secondary sexual characteristics in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii, where two female- and two male-determining alleles interact to produce siblings with four possible sex classes. We find that multiple alleles can produce modular variation in traits, including genital morphology, craniofacial morphology, gastrointestinal morphology, and home tank behaviors. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of multiple alleles in sex determination. (Less)

The retina is challenged by a variety of reactive oxygen species (ROS) that are generated by photoreceptors and by the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), a cell type that is also challenged by accumulations of bisretinoid lipofuscin. We sought to understand how intracellular iron (Fe) impacts the retina, given that Fe is a key component of ROS-generating enzymes and that Fe is also a component of bisretinoid lipofuscin. We found that intracellular Fe promotes the oxidation and degradation of bisretinoid lipofuscin. These findings have implications for the retina in general and for the RPE in particular, given that the RPE is challenged by accumulations of bisretinoid lipofuscin. Thus, our findings may have relevance for the prevention of age-related macular degeneration. (PsycINFO Database Record

Predators are the main drivers of biodiversity and ecosystem functioning, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key process in the organization of food webs. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as it leads to morphological and functional convergence. Here we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians, are an exception to this rule. We show that siphonophores can evolve from generalists to specialists on different prey types, and that these transitions are associated with specific evolutionary changes in the morphology of their tentacles. Our findings help understand how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also provide insights into the evolution of specialization in other predators.

The human hand is a complex structure that has changed little in the last two million years. However, the evolution of the hand is poorly understood because of a lack of fossils from the time when the first modern human-like species arose and spread across Africa. Here we show that a key derived feature of the hand, the third metacarpal styloid process, was present in a fossil from East Africa that lived ∼1.42 million years ago. This fossil thus provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key shared derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus. This fossil also provides the earliest evidence for the evolution of a derived hand in the genus Homo.

Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth, and thus requires a constant supply of one-carbon units. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a key regulator of this process. Here we show that dual knockout of SHMT1 and SHMT2 in cancer cells blocks tumor growth. We also identify a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT1/2, which is effective in cancer cells and in xenograft models. Finally, we show that one-carbon donor formate is a potent inhibitor of SHMT, and that this effect is reversed in cancer cells that are defective in glycine import. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells that can be exploited therapeutically. This work represents a major advance in our understanding of cancer metabolism, and has the potential to impact cancer treatment.

The role of forests in improving people’s diets is not well understood. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A adequacy. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A adequacy. These findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the importance of using causal inference methods to understand the effects of deforestation on people’s diets. This is a relatively new approach in the field of nutrition geography. We believe that this study will be of interest to researchers and policy makers interested in the role of forests in improving people’s diets and in the role of forests in improving people’s health more generally.

Mechanization has been a key driver of the Green Revolution, which has increased global food production by 100% since 1960. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We hypothesize that this trend is a consequence of the increasing size of farm machinery, which is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods.
